Well actually, it's Four Hundred Million (400,000,000) cellphone parts that nvidia cuda won.. If you count the processor and baseband radio chips separately. The Largest Cellphone Parts Order in the History of the Industry. And nvidia lost out on both parts. ( sigh ) Give it up, boys. Bashing Apple after losing that Elephantine order isn't gonna move nvda by one penny ($000.01). Nope. It'll just make folks think that Jen hired a bunch of incessant whiners.

Sounds like the Intel x86 Clover Trail beats the pants off the Tegra 3's little Ninja core in power management. Read all about it: Tegra 3 missed performance goals by wide margins

Topic.Title: One thing that frustrates me about nvidia, kai phone promises

Message.Msg: Making mulit-generational wealth on nvda is an art. 1. Sell on the promises and marketing hype. 2. Buy-to-Close on the delays and missed specs and lost orders. 3. Whistle on the way to the Bank. 4. Repeat with every chip generation. Remember all the Project Denver hype to took nvda to $26? Multi-generational wealth was made on THAT one for sure. The original Project Denver scheme to copycat a Genuine Intel x86 processor failed so badly that they Abandoned the project. Pity the frustrated folks that bought the hype at $26.

Message.Title: Intel's Rosepoint is here. The Intel Atom plus digital radio
Message.Msg: Man 'o Man! Those guys at Intel work fast. Much faster than the dawdlers at icera/nvidia, that's for sure. BEHOLD, BOYS! The first-ever Genuine Intel Atom processor -- with integrated digital radio. That's right -- all right there on the same little piece of Intel silicon. Like Qualcomm does. Google this, boys: How large is Intel's digital radio? Impressive, right? It sure is. But the question from nvidia shareholders is -- where the heck is nvidia's "Grey"? The acquisition of icera was announced May 9, 2011 for $367,000,000.00 of shareholder's cash -- for the sole purpose of putting a cheap little radio in the Tegra chips, right? And what has happened since, you ask? Delay after delay after delay after delay after delay. "End of 2013" is the latest word. As in, more than two-and-a-half YEARS after buying icera. As in, Still More Than a Year From Now. At best.....

Topic.Title: INtel's claim of Clover Trail TDP being 1.7 mW is completely misleading....this number applies only to an idle state

Message.Msg: Only 1.7W for a quad-threaded 1.8 GHz dual-core when going flat out which is half what the previous 3W single-core 1.5 GHz Z670 did so Intel have improved their tablet performance/watt by a factor of 4 going from 45nm to 32nm. arkDOTintelDOTcom/products/70105/Intel-Atom-Processor-Z2760-1MB-Cache-1_80-GHz arkDOTintelDOTcom/products/55663/ Both the cpu and gpu performance of Cloverview will exceed the 2W Tegra 3 by 50% at lower power and only 15% greater die size and unlike Nvidia they don't have to pay a foundry to make them making true net margins greater. It will also have full PC business legacy compatibility. eetimesDOTcom/electronics-news/4397303/Slideshow--Intel-carves-new-path-to-x86-tablets pcworldDOTcom/article/2010798/clover-trail-tablets-pitched-as-workplacefriendly.html The gpu will be a bit faster per clock than Apple's one ... POWERVR SGX545 delivers real-world performance of 40 million polygons/sec and 1 Gpixels/sec fillrate at 200MHz imgtecDOTcom/news/Release/index.asp?NewsID=516 POWERVR SGX543 delivers real-world performance of 35 million polygons/sec and 1 Gpixels/sec fillrate at 200MHz imgtecDOTcom/News/Release/index.asp?NewsID=428

That has already happened for netbooks. And of course, once that happens, will be like Detroit conceding small cars in the 70s.... once it got going, it encroaches UP. Ballmer can taking apart the whole PC ecosystem (bye bye HP, Dell, Acer, Lenovo.....) and learn a new way of making a living.... or he can be labeled as the guy who destroyed the franchise. Same for intel. Take apart the sweet margins and start selling $20 SoCs, or watch their processor market share fall apart. No more wintel tax. Go el goog go!

Topic.Title: INtel's claim of Clover Trail TDP being 1.7 mW is completely misleading....this number applies only to an idle state

Message.Msg: The new Intel x86 Clover Trail uses just 1.7 milliwatts of juice when it's in idle mode. Yet the Tegra 3 uses a whopping 100 milliwatts when that fifth little ninja core claims to be idling around -- but probably isn't. So Best? It's nvidia mismanagement again, right? Of the little nvidia ninja core. It's supposed to be in its little ninja bed -- asleep. But noooooo. It's up listening to tunes on its little ninja iPod, using its little ninja hairdryer, talking to its little ninja friends on its little ninja cellpone -- all sorts of stuff. Resulting in the little ninja core using a whole bunch of juice when it's in "idle". Clearly a total lack of ninja management. Again.

Topic.Title: One thing that frustrates me about nvidia, kai phone promises

Message.Msg: "Don't expect much phone penetration till integrated LTE....", writes getanid61 in denial. Dude -- Give it up. The SoC + integrated radio ship has sailed. Without nvidia. By the time dawdling nvidia get around to releasing its "Grey" chip in late 2013, they will be over Two Years behind Qualcomm, and One Year behind Intel. Who will do doubt be into their second generation LTE radios by then. And have all the best OEM's on long-term purchase orders already. The ship has sailed without nvidia. Again.

Topic.Title: Is this a good stock to hold For next.20years?

Message.Msg: She's only 3years old

Topic.Title: Is this a good stock to hold For next.20years?

Message.Msg: It's a leading edge technology stock, they are all risky calculated gambles over that length of period as the technology and competition can change so much over that period. You might want to take annual reviews if you do. This stock looks stable enough for the next year and might even rise a bit if the results are good. Stock is currently being bottled by all its moving averages which are overhead.

Topic.Title: Is this a good stock to hold For next.20years?

Message.Msg: Nvidia is not an OEM and is reliant on a popular big OEM first choosing it and then secondly having a commercially successful product. Neither is guaranteed over many years. So far Tegra 1, 2 and 3 have all been commercially unsuccessful in that they have collectively cost more to develop than the profit they have brought in. Meanwhile in 2013 Haswell and Xeon Phi will have Nvidia's core profitable businesses, GPU and PSB, clearly in its target sights ....

Message.Title: U.S. appeals court to Google: Your injunction in Germany is nonsense. Now go FRAND your patents.
Message.Msg: HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA ! Google/Motorola had won an injunction banning Microsoft's stuff in Germany, right? Microsoft appealed it. And the U.S. Appeals Court told Google/Motorola that their "injunction" in Germany was crapola -- and to license the disputed patents to Microsoft -- under FRAND (Fair, Reasonable, and Non-Discriminatory) terms. So Google/Motorola thought they had a Ban on Microsoft's stuff for the planet, -- starting with Germany -- and instead came out of the U.S. Appeals Court with nothing but a new garden-variety tear-it-off-the-pad FRAND licensee -- namely Microsoft. HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA ! You can "search" for news of Google's latest court Defeat by cutting-and-pasting this: Google loses appeal, continues to be barred from enforcing German injunction against Microsoft "The noose keeps tightening [on Google] and it appears to be only a question of when, not if, Motorola will have to extend a standard-essential patent license to Microsoft on truly FRAND terms."

Topic.Title: Tim has Cooked Apple - Put A Fork In It: It Is Done

Message.Msg: Source: Washington Post Ever find yourself frustrated with how smoothly Siri seems to work for the folks in Apple’s commercials but not for you? A New York man has filed a class-action suit against Apple, saying that the company has been “misleading and deceptive” about what the iPhone 4S virtual assistant can do. “For example,” the suit reads, “in many of Apple’s television advertisements, individuals are shown using Siri to make appointments, find restaurants and even learn the guitar chords to classic rock songs or how to tie a tie.” According to the plaintiff, Frank M. Fazio, the commercials have misled him to buy the iPhone 4S to get Siri but that he has had a lot of trouble using the software. The lawsuit claims that Apple’s advertisements are “fiction.” wwwDOTwashingtonpostDOTcom/business/technology/apple-hit-with-siri-suit-over-what-the-program-can-really-do/2012/03/13/gIQAYdmS9R_story.html

Topic.Title: U.S. appeals court to Google: Your injunction in Germany is nonsense. Now go FRAND your patents.

Message.Msg: So Best? Maybe Google could { wait for it now } SEARCH for a Higher Court? HA HA HA HA HA HA HA HA !

Topic.Title: Tim has Cooked Apple - Put A Fork In It: It Is Done

Message.Msg: While Apple have spent recent times mainly focused on accusing other companies of copying trivial things from their products (said to even include the shape of a rounded rectangle), they are now on the receiving end of such claims themselves, with a railway authority in Switzerland accusing the American technology giant of blatantly copying a famous clock design that they created in the 1940′s. The iOS6 system update for Apple products featured a facelift for a number of areas of basic service on their products, including their ‘clock’ app, which the state-owned Swiss Federal Railways company (Schweizerische Bundesbahnen, SBB) recognise as their own trademark, with claims that Apple have unlawfully copied the design (with their digital version appearing identical to the SBB’s) and that they are now drafting a lawsuit for compensation or removal of Apple’s clock. The design, which notably features a circular tip to the red ’second’ hand, was a creation of SBB employee Hans Hilfiker in 1944, and is commonly used in railway stations worldwide (particularly Switzerland) due to its global recognition for reliability, and also seen on watches from Mondaine, who hold a licence to use the patented design. An SBB spokesperson stated to local newspaper Tages-Anzeiger that while the company were pleased Apple paid tribute to the design by using it, they had no right to put it on their product. It is claimed that Apple have been in similar arguments over clocks before, only in 2009, they were the ones threatening app makers Tapbots due to their clock being ‘too similar’ to the one on iOS. The resemblance between the latest one on the operating system and the long-standing Swiss railway design, though, is one that is obvious, so surely this would class as part of the ‘stealing’ that Apple preach other companies not to do? They must have done something wrong here, as it probably takes a bit of added effort to annoy people in the world’s most politically-neutral country… Source: wwwDOTworldtvpcDOTcom/blog/apple-accused-of-stealing-design-like-swiss-clockwork/#ixzz280zEryw5
